You are here:

SALESFORCE HELP
DOCS
VISUALFORCE B2B COMMERCE
Create a Subscriber Template

If one of the default column layouts for a page's body content doesn't suit your requirements, you can create a custom layout, known as a subscriber template. With a subscriber template, you can specify your own arrangement of content that displays on a page between the navigational menu and the footer.

REQUIRED EDITIONS AND USER PERMISSIONS

Salesforce Compatibility

Salesforce Classic (not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.




B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)


USER PERMISSIONS NEEDED
To create Visualforce pages:	Customize Application
To access CC Admin and change settings:	Access B2B Commerce for Visualforce Admin Settings permission set

To create a subscriber template, we recommend that you copy the code from one of the default templates as a starting point. For example, maybe you want to modify the arrangement of widgets in the default three-column template.

IMPORTANT By default, B2B Commerce for Visualforce doesn’t support pages used within <iframe> elements.
Copy the default cc_tmpl_ThreeColRD template.
From Setup, enter Visualforce Pages in the Quick Find box, and then select Visualforce Pages.
Select cc_tmpl_ThreeColRD.
Select the template's default code, and copy it the clipboard.
Create a Visualforce page that contains your customizations.
To create a Visualforce page, complete the steps in Create Visualforce Pages.
Paste the copy that you copied from the default template.
Delete the controller="ccrz.cc_ctrl_StorefrontTemplate" attribute from the opening <apex:page> tag.
To ensure that the Visualforce page renders correctly, include each of the following attributes in the opening <apex:page> tag:
sidebar="false"
showHeader="false"
standardStylesheets="false"
applyHtmlTag="false"
<apex:page id="cc_example_customThreeColTemplate" docType="html-5.0" sidebar="false" showHeader="false" standardStylesheets="false" applyHtmlTag="false">
Delete all lines from <!-- LEGACY BLOCK BEGIN --> to <!-- END LEGACY BLOCK -->.
NOTE The legacy code block defines template information for a Bootstrap 2.3.2-enabled storefront. We recommend that new solutions always use the Bootstrap 3 library.
Delete the following opening and closing tags:
<apex:composition>
<apex:define>
<c:ifConfigValue>
<c:cc_SFLiveChatWidget>
Move or remove the remaining components.
Save your changes.
To use your custom Visualforce page on your storefront, update your storefront configuration settings.
On the CC Admin tab in your org, select your storefront (1).
In the Storefront Settings menu, select Configuration Settings (2).
From the Module picklist, select Template (3).
Click New  (4), enter the following values in the New Page Setting window, and click Create.
FIELD	VALUE
Module	Template
Configuration	Visualforce Page
Page	The page where you want to use the subscriber template.
Value	The Visualforce page that you created. Because this page is subscriber code that you've created and is outside of the managed package, prefix the page name with c__, such as c__cc_example_customThreeColTemplate.
Find the Name configuration for the page whose layout you want to change. For example, to change the layout of the Home page, find the Name configuration where Page is Home (5).
Click the Visualforce page entered in the Value column (6).
Enter cc_tmpl_SubscriberTemplate, and click the blue checkmark  to accept.
NOTE The cc_tmpl_SubscriberTemplate value is a hard-coded string that indicates that you want to use a subscriber template.
Build and activate a new configuration cache.
SEE ALSO
Modify the Column Layout of a Storefront Page
Salesforce Help Create Visualforce Pages
(Salesforce Developers) apex:composition
(Salesforce Developers) apex:define
(Salesforce Developers) apex:page

title: Customizing Storefront Layouts with Subscriber Templates
